passage:
(1) The science of aging, known formally as biogerontology, seeks to understand the biological mechanisms that drive the aging process in humans and other organisms. While aging was once considered an inevitable and immutable process, researchers have made significant strides in identifying specific cellular and molecular pathways that contribute to senescence, the gradual deterioration of functional characteristics associated with aging. These discoveries have shifted our understanding from viewing aging as simply the passage of time to recognizing it as a complex biological phenomenon that may be amenable to intervention.

(2) At the cellular level, several key processes have been implicated in aging. Telomere shortening, which occurs each time a cell divides, eventually leads to cellular senescence when these protective chromosome caps become critically short. Mitochondrial dysfunction progressively impairs the cell's ability to produce energy efficiently, while the accumulation of damaged proteins and cellular waste overwhelms cleanup mechanisms. Additionally, chronic low-grade inflammation, termed

disrupts normal tissue function throughout the body, and epigenetic changes alter gene expression patterns in ways that compromise cellular resilience.

(3) Caloric restriction remains one of the most well-established interventions shown to extend lifespan in numerous experimental models. By reducing caloric intake while maintaining essential nutrients, organisms from yeast to primates exhibit remarkable extensions in both lifespan and healthspan—the period of life spent in good health. The beneficial effects appear to be mediated through multiple pathways, including reduced oxidative stress, enhanced cellular repair mechanisms, and activation of longevity genes. More recently, intermittent fasting regimens have demonstrated similar benefits, potentially offering a more practical approach for human application.

(4) Pharmaceutical approaches to aging have also shown promise in laboratory settings. Compounds like rapamycin, metformin, and senolytics (drugs that eliminate senescent cells) have extended lifespan in various model organisms. These interventions target fundamental aging pathways such as nutrient sensing, cellular energy production, and the accumulation of senescent cells. Several are now undergoing human clinical trials specifically designed to target aging processes rather than individual diseases, representing a paradigm shift in how medicine approaches age-related decline.

(5) While significant ethical and practical challenges remain in translating these findings to human interventions, the field has moved beyond simply describing aging to actively developing strategies to modify its progression. The goal is not necessarily radical life extension but rather to compress morbidity—reducing the period of disability and disease at the end of life while extending healthy, functional years. This approach recognizes that the quality of additional years matters as much as their quantity, focusing on extending healthspan alongside lifespan. As research continues, the once fantastical notion of meaningfully intervening in human aging processes increasingly appears within scientific reach.

questions.question: Which verb form correctly completes the sentence? 'She _____ in this city since 2010.'

options.A: lives
options.B: is living
options.C: has lived

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct use of articles:

options.A: He is best student in the class.
options.B: She bought a umbrella yesterday.
options.C: The happiness is what everyone seeks.
options.D: I need an hour to finish this report.

questions.question: Choose the correct passive form: 'The new policy _____ next month.'

options.A: will implement
options.B: is implementing
options.C: will be implemented

questions.question: Which sentence contains a correct conditional form?

options.A: If I will see him, I will tell him the news.
options.B: If I saw him, I would tell him the news.
options.C: If I would see him, I would tell him the news.
options.D: If I had seen him, I will tell him the news.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct relative clause:

options.A: The woman which works in that office is my cousin.
options.B: The book who I borrowed is very interesting.
options.C: The city where I grew up has changed a lot.
options.D: The man which I met yesterday is a doctor.

questions.question: Choose the correct word order:

options.A: She explained carefully the procedure to us.
options.B: She carefully explained the procedure to us.
options.C: She explained the procedure carefully to us.
options.D: She explained to us carefully the procedure.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct subject-verb agreement:

options.A: The quality of these products are excellent.
options.B: Each of the students have completed the assignment.
options.C: Neither of the options is suitable for our needs.
options.D: The committee are divided on this issue.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the past perfect tense correctly?

options.A: After I had finished my homework, I went to bed.
options.B: After I finished my homework, I had gone to bed.
options.C: After I have finished my homework, I went to bed.
options.D: After I was finishing my homework, I had gone to bed.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct use of modals:

options.A: You must to attend the meeting tomorrow.
options.B: She could solving the problem without help.
options.C: We might be late for the concert.
options.D: They should to consider all options carefully.

questions.question: Select the correct comparative form:

options.A: This book is more interesting than any book I've read.
options.B: This book is more interesting than any other book I've read.
options.C: This book is the more interesting of all books I've read.
options.D: This book is interestinger than the one I read last week.

questions.question: Choose the correct form for reported speech: "I will call you tomorrow," she said.

options.A: She said she will call me tomorrow.
options.B: She said she would call me the next day.
options.C: She said she will call me the next day.
options.D: She said she would call me tomorrow.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct use of the gerund:

options.A: I enjoy to swim in the ocean.
options.B: She suggested to go to the museum.
options.C: They admitted stealing the documents.
options.D: We look forward to seeing you again.

options.A: Walking in the park, the birds were singing loudly.
options.B: Having finished the report, she decided to take a break.
options.C: Seen from a distance, I thought it was a different building.
options.D: Reading the instructions, the machine was difficult to assemble.

options.A: know

options.D: After considering all the options: we decided to postpone the trip.

questions.question: According to paragraph 1, how has scientific understanding of aging changed?

options.A: Aging is now considered a purely psychological process
options.B: Aging has been proven to be completely preventable
options.C: Aging is now viewed as a complex biological phenomenon that may be modifiable
options.D: Scientists have discovered that aging affects only certain organisms

questions.question: The word 'senescence' in paragraph 1 most likely means:

options.A: The process of growing younger
options.B: The biological process of aging
options.C: A medical condition affecting the elderly

questions.question: According to paragraph 2, what happens to telomeres during the aging process?

options.A: They become longer with each cell division
options.B: They remain unchanged throughout life
options.C: They become critically short after repeated cell divisions
options.D: They cause inflammation in body tissues

questions.question: Based on paragraph 3, what is 'healthspan'?

options.A: A type of dietary supplement
options.B: The total length of a person's life
options.C: The period of life spent in good health

questions.question: Which intervention is described as the most well-established for extending lifespan?

options.A: Pharmaceutical drugs
options.B: Caloric restriction
options.C: Telomere extension

questions.question: According to paragraph 4, what is unique about the current clinical trials for compounds like rapamycin and metformin?

options.A: They are designed to target fundamental aging processes rather than specific diseases
options.B: They are only being tested on animals
options.C: They are focused exclusively on treating cancer
options.D: They are only available to wealthy individuals

questions.question: The term 'compress morbidity' in paragraph 5 most likely refers to:

options.A: Treating individual diseases more effectively
options.B: Reducing the period of disability and disease at the end of life
options.C: Extending total lifespan regardless of health quality

questions.question: Based on the passage, what would be the primary goal of aging interventions?

options.A: To make people live forever
options.B: To prevent all age-related diseases
options.C: To extend healthy, functional years of life
options.D: To reverse the aging process completely

questions.question: What does the author imply about the field of aging research?

options.A: It has made little progress in recent decades
options.B: It focuses primarily on cosmetic aspects of aging
options.C: It has moved from description to active intervention development
options.D: It is primarily concerned with radical life extension

questions.question: The author's tone in this passage can best be described as:

options.A: Highly skeptical of aging research
options.B: Informative and cautiously optimistic
options.C: Dismissive of traditional views on aging
